Dvořák: Fiolinkonsert|Bergen Filharmonis.work_title: Violin Concerto in A minor, Op. 53
Dvořák: Fiolinkonsert|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: The Violin Concerto in A minor, Op. 53 was composed between 1879 and 1882. It is one of Dvořák's most popular and frequently performed works.

Matre: Freude|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkes.notes: Commissioned by the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra for the 2025/26 season, relating to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. The piece uses the same orchestration as Beethoven but without vocal soloists, focusing on the first word, 'Freude' (Joy). It was written during a time of global unrest and uncertainty. Premiered on September 4, 2025, by the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra.

Mozarts Requiem|Bergen Filharmoniske Ork.notes: Incomplete work at the time of Mozart's death, completed by Franz Xaver Süssmayr.

Chin: Subito con forza|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: A short orchestral composition written in 2020 by Unsuk Chin as a miniature tribute to Ludwig van Beethoven. The work is scored for an orchestra consisting of two flutes, two oboes, two clarinets, two bassoons, two horns, two trumpets, timpani, two percussionists, piano, and strings.

Musikalske eventyr: Beethoven|Bergen Fil.notes: Compilation of musical adventures by Beethoven

Musikalske eventyr Prometeus og Eroica|B.notes: Also known as Die Geschöpfe des Prometheus, is a ballet composed in 1801. The ballet premiered on March 28, 1801, in Vienna. Beethoven based the fourth movement of his Eroica symphony on the main theme of the Finale of this ballet.

Orff: Carmina Burana|Bergen Filharmonisk.notes: A scenic cantata based on 24 poems from the medieval collection Carmina Burana.

Mahler 8|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester..notes: Also known as 'Symphony of a Thousand'. Composed in 1906. Part I is based on the Latin text of Veni creator spiritus, and Part II is a setting of the words from the closing scene of Goethe's Faust.

Brahms: Ein deutsches Requiem|Bergen Fil.notes: A large-scale work for chorus, orchestra, and soloists, composed between 1865 and 1868. It comprises seven movements.

Ravel: Pavane for en død prinsesse|Berge.notes: Also known as Pavane for a Dead Princess. Originally written for solo piano in 1899 and orchestrated in 1910. The piece evokes a pavane that a little princess might have danced at the Spanish court in former times.

Bacewicz: Ouverture|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Also known as Overture for Orchestra. Composed in 1943.

Nielsen: Klarinettkonsert|Bergen Filharm.notes: Written for Aage Oxenvad in 1928. The concerto is in one long movement with four distinct theme groups.

Rakhmaninov: Pianokonsert nr. 3|Bergen F.work_title: Piano Concerto No. 3 in D minor

Rakhmaninov: Klokkene, korsymfoni|Bergen.notes: Choral symphony based on Edgar Allan Poe's poem 'The Bells'. Also referred to as a choral symphony.

Mahler: Das Lied von der Erde|Bergen Fil.notes: A symphony for tenor and alto (or baritone) voice and orchestra. The texts are based on 'The Chinese Flute' by Hans Bethge.

Beethoven: Romanse nr. 2|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Composed around 1798, published in 1805. Also known as Romance for violin and orchestra No. 2. It is speculated that it might have originally been a slow movement for an unfinished violin concerto in C major.

Hagen: Kunstnerens fortvilelse foran de.work_title: Kunstnerens fortvilelse foran de antikke fragmenters storhet
Hagen: Kunstnerens fortvilelse foran de.work_title_norwegian: Kunstnerens fortvilelse foran de antikke fragmenters storhet

Mahler: Symfoni nr. 1|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Composed mainly between late 1887 and March 1888. The first performance was in Budapest in 1889. Some performances and recordings call the work 'Titan'.

Lutoslawski: Cellokonsert|Bergen Filharm.notes: The Cello Concerto was composed in 1970 and was commissioned by the Royal Philharmonic Society. It was dedicated to Mstislav Rostropovich, who premiered the work on October 14, 1970. The concerto consists of four movements played without pause: Introduction, Four Episodes, Cantilena, and Finale. It is scored for solo cello and a large orchestra.

Anderson: Eden|Bergen Filharmoniske Orke.notes: Written for the Cheltenham Festival in 2005. An exploration of the non-tempered tuning of the harmonic series.

Brahms: Symfoni nr. 3|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Composed in 1883. Also known as Brahms's Third.

Mozart: Rondo i D-dur|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Also known as Rondo No. 1. The Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester recording was made on 2023-01-26.

Mozart: Ballettmusikk fra Idomeneo|Berge.notes: Ballet music from the opera Idomeneo. Also known as Ballettmusik zur Oper Idomeneo. The ballet music was composed in 1780-81 and assigned Köchel number 367.

Mozart: Pianokonsert nr. 21|Bergen Filha.work_title: Piano Concerto No. 21 in C major, K. 467
Mozart: Pianokonsert nr. 21|Bergen Filha.notes: Also known as Piano Concerto No. 21 in C (K.467). Composed in 1785. It has three movements: Allegro maestoso, Andante, and Allegro vivace assai.

Wagner: Parsifal|Bergen Filharmoniske Or.notes: Music drama in three acts. Wagner's last opera. Libretto based on the 13th-century Middle High German chivalric romance Parzival.

Mahler: Symfoni nr. 2 \"Oppstandelsen\"|.notes: Also known as the Resurrection Symphony, written between 1888 and 1894. First performed in 1895. The work has five movements.

Sæverud: Symfoni nr. 7 \"Salme\"|Bergen.notes: Also known as Psalm. A hymn of thanksgiving for peace.

Sæverud: Fanfare og hymne|Bergen Filharm.notes: Written to a commission from the City of Bergen.

Vaage: Janus|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkest.notes: Commissioned work for flute and orchestra. 'Janus' is a being with two faces. In Roman mythology, this is the god of gates and doors, all beginnings and every end. Janus is depicted with two faces on one head where the faces are turned in opposite directions. One looks into the future, the other towards the past.

Delius: Eine Messe des Lebens|Bergen Fil.notes: A cantata based on Friedrich Nietzsche's philosophical novel Thus Spoke Zarathustra. Also known as A Mass of Life.

Tjøgersen: Between Trees|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Piece won the International Rostrum of Composers in Palermo in 2022. Tjøgersen describes the piece as 'chamber music for orchestra'. The world premiere was in October 2021.

Nielsen: Symfoni nr. 3|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Also known as 'Sinfonia Espansiva'. It is unique in his symphonic output for having vocal parts, specifically wordless solos for soprano and baritone in the second movement. The symphony was written between 1910 and 1911.

Por una cabeza|Bergen Filharmoniske Orke.notes: Tango song written in 1935 with music by Carlos Gardel and lyrics by Alfredo Le Pera.

Thoresen: Emergence – Luohti boaðe!|Berg.notes: Reflects the Sami joik tradition. Symphonic poem.

Chopin pianokonsert nr. 1 med Aleksandra.work_title: Piano Concerto No. 1 in E minor, Op. 11

Griegs a-moll med Zifan Ye|Bergen Filhar.work_title: Piano Concerto in A minor, Op. 16
Griegs a-moll med Zifan Ye|Bergen Filhar.notes: One of Grieg's most popular works. Composed in 1868. Grieg's only completed piano concerto.

The Kitchen Department - English version.notes: Recorded with the Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester on 2022-07-05. 'The Kitchen Department' may refer to a department in a hotel or the duties and responsibilities of kitchen staff. It may also refer to the film 'The Kitchen'.

Kjøkkenavdelingen|Bergen Filharmoniske O.notes: Recorded by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester on 2022-07-02

Matre: Konsert for slagverk og orkester|.notes: Premiered January 13, 2022. Composed in two parts, the second part was composed in the spring of 2021.

Schumann: Konsert for piano og orkester|.work_title: Piano Concerto in A minor, Op. 54
Schumann: Konsert for piano og orkester|.notes: Robert Schumann's Piano Concerto in A minor, Op. 54, is his only piano concerto. It was completed in 1845. The complete work was premiered in Dresden on December 4, 1845. It is one of the most widely performed and recorded piano concertos from the Romantic period.

Ryan Wigglesworth: Magnificat|Bergen Fil.notes: Composed by Ryan Wigglesworth. Co-commissioned by the Bergen Philharmonic and Hallé. First performed by the Bergen Philharmonic. Dedicated to Sophie Bevan.

Alpesymfonien|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkes.notes: A tone poem for large orchestra, depicting a mountain climb in the Alps.

Hurra for deg! Fødselsdagshilsen til Kon.work_title_norwegian: Hurra for deg som fyller ditt år!
Hurra for deg! Fødselsdagshilsen til Kon.notes: Norwegian birthday song. The melody is a Norwegian folk tune. The song was first printed in 1911 in the book 'Saa leker vi litt'.

Parsifal, forspill til 1. akt|Bergen Fil.notes: Music drama in three acts. Forspill til 1. akt means Prelude to Act 1.

Lontano|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester. I.notes: Composed in 1967. Used in the films 'The Shining' and 'Shutter Island'.

Ravel: Le Tombeau de Couperin|Bergen Fil.notes: Originally a suite for solo piano composed between 1914 and 1917. Ravel orchestrated four of the six movements in 1919. Each movement is dedicated to the memory of a friend who died in World War I.

Mozart: Symfoni nr. 35 \"Haffner\"|Berge.work_title: Symphony No. 35 in D major, K. 385
Mozart: Symfoni nr. 35 \"Haffner\"|Berge.notes: Also known as the Haffner Symphony. Commissioned by the Haffner family of Salzburg. Originally a serenade for the ennoblement of Sigmund Haffner the Younger. The symphony was completed between July and August 1782.

Elgar: Cellokonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Composed in 1919, Elgar's Cello Concerto in E minor, Op. 85, is a cornerstone of the cello repertoire. It is Elgar's last major completed work. The concerto is scored for solo cello, 2 flutes, 2 oboes, 2 clarinets in A, 2 bassoons, 4 horns in F, 2 trumpets in C, 3 trombones, tuba, timpani, and strings. The work is dedicated to Sidney Colvin and his wife.

Berlioz: Symphonie fantastique|Bergen Fi.notes: Also known as Episode de la vie d'un Artiste [:] Symphonie Fantastique en 5 parties. The symphony depicts an artist who poisons himself with opium in a fit of hopelessness. Berlioz provided extensive program notes for each section.

Caroline Shaw: Entr'acte|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Entr'acte was written in 2011 after Caroline Shaw heard the Brentano Quartet play Haydn's Op. 77, No. 2. It is structured like a minuet and trio, riffing on that classical form. It exists in versions for string quartet and string orchestra.

Musikalske eventyr: Snødronningen|Bergen.notes: Based on the fairy tale 'The Snow Queen' by Hans Christian Andersen. Several composers have created works based on this tale. 'Musikalske eventyr' suggests this is a compilation of musical pieces.

Musikalske eventyr: Daphnis & Chloe|Berg.notes: Ballet and orchestral concert work, subtitled symphonie chorégraphique (choreographic symphony), for orchestra and wordless chorus. There are also two suites extracted from the ballet.

If my complaints could Passions move|Ber.work_title: If my complaints could passions move

Leos Janáček: Capriccio|Bergen Filharmon.work_title: Capriccio for Piano Left-Hand and Chamber Ensemble
Leos Janáček: Capriccio|Bergen Filharmon.notes: Also known as 'Defiance' (Vzdor). Written in 1926 for piano left-hand, flute, two trumpets, three trombones and tenor tuba. Inspired by pianist Otakar Hollmann. Consists of four movements: Allegro, Adagio, Allegretto, and Andante.

Franck: Le chasseur maudit|Bergen Filhar.notes: Symphonic poem inspired by Gottfried August Bürger's ballad Der wilde Jäger.

Sibelius: Symfoni nr. 1|Bergen Filharmon.notes: The Symphony No. 1 in E minor, Op. 39, is a four-movement work for orchestra written from 1898 to 1899 by Jean Sibelius. The work was first performed on April 26, 1899, and revised in 1900. The symphony is characterized by its use of string and woodwind solos.

Marius Neset: Every little Step|Bergen F.notes: Piece for full orchestra without saxophone, commissioned by Bergen Philharmonic

Strauss: Obokonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Composed in 1945. Also known as Concerto in D major for Oboe and Small Orchestra. The work consists of three interconnected movements: Allegro moderato, Andante, and Vivace – Allegro.

Wagner: Forspill til Mestersangerne fra.notes: The recording is of the overture to the opera 'Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg'.

Sæveruds Peer Gynt|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Incidental music to Henrik Ibsen's play. In the 1950s, Sæverud compiled 13 movements from the stage music into two orchestral suites: Peer Gynt Suite No. 1, Op. 28 I (6 movements) and Peer Gynt Suite No. 2, Op. 28 II (7 movements).

Knut Vaage: Relieff|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Work for cello and orchestra. First performed in Bergen, 2021. Nominated for Årets verk (Work of the Year) in 2022.

Sibelius: Symfoni nr. 6|Bergen Filharmon.work_title: Symphony No. 6 in D minor, Op. 104
Sibelius: Symfoni nr. 6|Bergen Filharmon.notes: The Symphony No. 6 in D minor, Op. 104, is a four-movement work for orchestra written from 1914 to 1923 by Jean Sibelius. The composer called the work "cold spring water" in opposition to many contemporary "cocktails"—a reference to the modernist gestures in post-war music. A typical performance lasts about 27 minutes. The symphony is usually described as being in D minor; much of it is in fact in the (modern) Dorian mode.

Sevåg: European Memories|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Concerto for Bassoon and Orchestra. Premiered on January 21, 2021, by Per Hannevold and the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra. The piece is divided into four movements.

Schubert/Berio: Rendering|Bergen Filharm.notes: Composition by Luciano Berio, based on fragments of Schubert's unfinished Symphony No. 10 in D major, D 936A.

Julekonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkeste.notes: A 'Julekonsert' is a Christmas concert in Norway, often featuring a mix of traditional Norwegian Christmas carols, classical pieces, and sometimes international Christmas songs translated into Norwegian. The Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester has performed Julekonserter with varied programs.

Rakhmaninov: Symfoniske danser|Bergen Fi.notes: Orchestral suite in three movements. This was Rachmaninoff's last completed work.

Tveitt: Tri fjordar|Bergen Filharmoniske.work_title: Concerto for Hardanger Fiddle and Orchestra No. 2 "Tri fjordar"
Tveitt: Tri fjordar|Bergen Filharmoniske.work_title_norwegian: Konsert for hardingfela og orkester nr. 2 Tri fjordar
Tveitt: Tri fjordar|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Also known as Three Fjords. Composed in 1965. Includes movements named Hardanger, Sogn and Nordfjord.

Mendelssohn: Symfoni nr. 1|Bergen Filhar.notes: Completed on March 31, 1824, when Mendelssohn was 15 years old. Dedicated to the Philharmonic Society.

Vaughan Wiliams: Serenade to Music|Berge.notes: Orchestral concert work completed in 1938. Written as a tribute to conductor Sir Henry Wood. Features lyrics adapted from Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice. Originally scored for 16 soloists and orchestra, later arranged for smaller forces.

Sibelius: Symfoni nr. 7|Bergen Filharmon.notes: A single-movement work for orchestra. Also known as Fantasia sinfonica No. 1 at its premiere.

Tsjaikovskij: Variasjoner over et rokokk.notes: Tchaikovsky's Variations on a Rococo Theme, Op. 33, for cello and orchestra, was written between 1876 and 1877. The style was inspired by Mozart. The work is composed of a theme and eight variations. The original version was reconstructed and published in 1956.

Halvorsen: Mascarade-suite|Bergen Filhar.notes: Incidental music for Ludvig Holberg's play 'Mascarade', originally scored for a small orchestra. The original suite had nine movements.

Ouverture til Skjebnens makt|Bergen Filh.work_title: Overture to La forza del destino
Ouverture til Skjebnens makt|Bergen Filh.notes: The overture is from the opera 'La forza del destino' (The Force of Destiny). The opera's libretto was written by Francesco Maria Piave. The overture is a standard repertoire piece for orchestras.

Sibelius: Valse triste|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Originally incidental music for the play 'Kuolema'

Beethoven: Symfoni nr. 7|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Composed between 1811 and 1812. The work is dedicated to Count Moritz von Fries. The premiere took place in Vienna on December 8, 1813.

Sibelius: Symfoni nr. 3|Bergen Filharmon.notes: Composed from 1904 to 1907. Also known as Symphony No. 3 in C major, Op. 52. It consists of three movements.

Sibelius: Andante Festivo|Bergen Filharm.notes: Originally a string quartet in 1922, arranged for string orchestra and timpani in 1938. Sibelius conducted the string orchestra version in a live broadcast on January 1, 1939.

Vasks: Bratsjkonsert|Bergen Filharmonisk.work_title: Concerto for Viola and String Orchestra

Beethoven: Symfoni nr. 5 \"Skjebnesymfon.notes: Also known as the Fate Symphony. Composed between 1804 and 1808. One of the most well-known compositions in classical music.

Hummel: Trompetkonsert|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Also known as Concerto a Trombe Principale. Originally written in E major, but often performed in E-flat major. Composed in 1803 for keyed trumpet virtuoso Anton Weidinger. Instrumentation: keyed trumpet solo, flute, 2 oboes, 2 clarinets, 2 horns, timpani, and strings.

Symfoni nr. 31 \"Paris\"|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Also known as the 'Paris' Symphony. Composed in 1778. It was Mozart's first symphony to use clarinets.

James Gaffigan dirigerer Rameau, Ravel o.notes: The concert includes orchestral suites by Rameau, Ravel, and Mozart. Rameau's orchestral music comes from his operas and ballets. He is considered a pioneer in imaginative orchestration.

Erik Byes vakreste sanger|Bergen Filharm.notes: Compilation of Erik Bye's most beautiful songs performed with the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra

Lachrymae|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester..notes: A collection of instrumental music published in 1604, consisting of seven slow pieces called 'tears' and other pieces. The seven pavans are variations on a theme, the 'Lachrimae pavan'. Also exists as a lute solo and a song.

Henry Purcell: Begravelses-musikk|Bergen.notes: Also known as Funeral Music for Queen Mary. Composed for the funeral of Queen Mary II in March 1695. Scored for SATB chorus, four trumpets, and basso continuo.

Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis|Ber.work_title: Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis
Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis|Ber.notes: Based on a theme by Thomas Tallis. Composed in 1910 for string orchestra, string quartet, and double string orchestra. Also known as the Tallis Fantasia.

Nordheim: Clamavi|Bergen Filharmoniske O.notes: Clamavi (1980) per violoncello solo, was inspired by Psalm 141. It is the only piece Nordheim wrote for solo cello.

Rameau: Les indes galantes, suite|Bergen.notes: Les Indes galantes is a ballet héroïque (opera-ballet) by Jean-Philippe Rameau, first performed in 1735. It consists of a prologue and four entrées. It is considered one of Rameau's most famous works.

Copland: Klarinettkonsert|Bergen Filharm.notes: Composed between 1947 and 1948, the Clarinet Concerto was commissioned by Benny Goodman. The piece is in two movements played without pause, connected by a cadenza for the solo instrument. The instrumentation includes clarinet with strings, harp, and piano.

Grieg, Delius, Vaughan Williams og Britt.notes: Focusing on Grieg as the first composer listed. The recording likely includes selections from his orchestral works. Peer Gynt Suite No. 1, Op. 46 is a possibility.

Mozart: Symfoni nr. 41 ''Jupiter''|Berge.notes: Also known as the Jupiter Symphony. Completed on August 10, 1788. The longest and last symphony that Mozart composed.

Haydn: Cellokonsert i C-dur|Bergen Filha.work_title: Cello Concerto No. 1 in C major, Hob. VIIb/1
Haydn: Cellokonsert i C-dur|Bergen Filha.notes: Composed around 1761–1765. The work was presumed lost until 1961, when musicologist Oldřich Pulkert discovered a copy of the score at the Prague National Museum.

Copland: Appalachian Spring|Bergen Filha.notes: Ballet music later arranged as an orchestral work.

Copland: Quiet City|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Originally incidental music for Irwin Shaw's play of the same name. Later arranged as a composition for trumpet, cor anglais (or oboe), and string orchestra.

Copland: Fanfare for the Common Man|Berg.notes: Written in 1942 for the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Inspired by a speech by Vice President Henry A. Wallace. It was premiered on March 12, 1943.

Schumann: Symfoni nr. 4|Bergen Filharmon.work_title: Symphony No. 4 in D minor, Op. 120
Schumann: Symfoni nr. 4|Bergen Filharmon.notes: Also known as Symfoni nr. 4. The symphony was first completed in 1841 and heavily revised in 1851. The movements are meant to flow into each other creating an unbroken flow of music.

Schönberg: kammersymfoni|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Also known as Kammersymphonie. The Chamber Symphony No. 1 in E major, Op. 9, was completed in 1906. It is scored for 15 solo instruments. The work is in one movement, but can be subdivided into five continuous sections.

Gabrieli: Sonata pian' e forte|Bergen Fi.notes: Composed in 1597. One of the first works to specify instrumentation and dynamics. Written for eight instruments divided into two groups. The term 'sonata' at this time meant a piece for instruments.

Griegsanger med Mari Eriksmoen|Bergen Fi.notes: Compilation of songs by Edvard Grieg performed by Mari Eriksmoen and Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester

Gabrieli, Britten og Schönberg|Bergen Fi.notes: Concert includes works by Gabrieli, Britten, and Schönberg

Halvorsen: Passacaglia|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Passacaglia based on a theme by Handel. Originally for violin and viola (or cello), orchestrated for orchestra.

Aaron Copland - Et musikalsk portrett|Be.notes: The recording is a musical portrait of Aaron Copland performed by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester, recorded on 2020-05-07

Craig Farr: Alrekr - The Towering, for f.work_title: Alrekr - The Towering, for five Percussionists and Electronics
Craig Farr: Alrekr - The Towering, for f.notes: Work for five percussionists and electronics, performed by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester

Farr: Alrekr - The Towering|Bergen Filha.notes: Recorded by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester on 2020-04-30

Craig Farr: Alrekr – The Towering|Bergen.notes: Recorded April 30, 2020 with the Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester

Dvorak: Terzetto|Bergen Filharmoniske Or.notes: The Terzetto in C major, Op. 74, is a chamber work for two violins and viola by Antonín Dvořák, written in 1887. It consists of four movements. Dvořák also wrote an easier work for the same instruments, known as Miniatures, Op. 75a.

Delius: On Hearing the First Cuckoo in S.work_title: On Hearing the First Cuckoo in Spring
Delius: On Hearing the First Cuckoo in S.notes: A tone poem composed in 1912. It is one of Delius's Two Pieces for Small Orchestra. The first performance was in Leipzig on October 23, 1913.

Dvorák, Halvorsen og Tsjaikovskij|Bergen.notes: Compilation of works by Dvorák, Halvorsen and Tchaikovsky performed by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester

Grieg: Pinsesalme|Bergen Filharmoniske O.notes: Part of Peer Gynt, Op. 23. Also known as Whitsun Hymn.

Sæverud: Kjempevise-slåtten|Bergen Filha.notes: Also known as Ballad of Revolt, composed in 1943. There are versions for both solo piano and symphony orchestra. The title refers to both the resistance movement and the folk ballad tradition. Inspired by the sight of German barracks in Lærdal.

Ulvo: Woven Fingerprints|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Composed by Therese Birkelund Ulvo. Performed by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester. Recorded 2020-03-05

Daphnis et Chloé|Bergen Filharmoniske Or.notes: Ballet and orchestral concert work, subtitled symphonie chorégraphique (choreographic symphony), for orchestra and wordless chorus. There are also two suites extracted from the ballet.

Mahler: Symfoni nr. 9|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Composed between 1908 and 1909, Mahler's Symphony No. 9 was the last symphony he completed. A typical performance lasts approximately 75 to 90 minutes. Mahler did not live to see its premiere.

Oh Giselle, remember me...|Bergen Filhar.notes: Giselle is a romantic ballet in two acts. The ballet premiered in Paris in 1841.

Lohengrin, forspill til tredje akt|Berge.notes: The prelude to Act III of Lohengrin is a well-known orchestral excerpt from the opera. Lohengrin is a Romantic opera in three acts. The opera premiered in 1850.

Luther Adams: Become Ocean|Bergen Filhar.notes: Become Ocean is an orchestral composition by John Luther Adams, inspired by the oceans of Alaska and the Pacific Northwest. It premiered in 2013 and won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for Music. The work is approximately 42 minutes in length.

Tsjaikovskij Symfoni nr. 5|Bergen Filha.work_title: Symphony No. 5 in E minor, Op. 64
Tsjaikovskij Symfoni nr. 5|Bergen Filha.notes: Composed between May and August 1888. First performed in Saint Petersburg on November 17, 1888. The symphony is cyclical, with a recurring main theme in all four movements.

Matre Lyric Pieces|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: A collection of 66 short pieces for solo piano written by Edvard Grieg, published in 10 volumes. Some pieces were later orchestrated.

Bruch Fiolinkonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.work_title: Violin Concerto No. 1 in G minor, Op. 26
Bruch Fiolinkonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: One of Bruch's most famous works. The concerto was completed in 1866 and revised in 1867. Joseph Joachim assisted Bruch with the solo part.

Brahms: Symfoni nr. 4|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Composed in 1884-1885. Also known as Sinfonie Nr.4. It is the last of Brahms' symphonies. The premiere was on October 25, 1885.

Whitacre: Deep Field|Bergen Filharmonisk.notes: Inspired by the Hubble Space Telescope's Deep Field image. Premiered in 2015. Includes a virtual choir.

Mahler: Symfoni nr. 4|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Composed from 1899 to 1900, incorporates a song originally written in 1892. The song, 'Das himmlische Leben', presents a child's vision of heaven. Smaller in orchestration and shorter in length than Mahler's earlier symphonies. The premiere was in Munich on 25 November 1901.

Grob tvoi, Spase|Bergen Filharmoniske Or.notes: Performed by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester, recorded 2019-04-12

Stravinsky: Salmesymfonien|Bergen Filhar.notes: Composed in 1930 during Stravinsky's neoclassical period. Commissioned for the 50th anniversary of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The texts are from the Vulgate versions in Latin.

Beethoven: Symfoni nr. 3 \"Eroica\"|Berg.work_title: Symphony No. 3 in E-flat major, Op. 55
Beethoven: Symfoni nr. 3 \"Eroica\"|Berg.notes: Also known as the Eroica Symphony. It is considered a landmark in the transition between the Classical and Romantic eras. The symphony was mainly composed in 1803-1804. Beethoven initially intended to dedicate the symphony to Napoleon Bonaparte.

Schönberg: Pelleas und Melisande|Bergen.notes: Symphonic poem based on Maurice Maeterlinck's play. Recorded February 15, 2019.

Bach: Juleoratoriet|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: A cycle of six cantatas for the Christmas season. It was composed for the Christmas season of 1734-1735. The work incorporates music from earlier compositions.

Bartók: Ridder Blåskjeggs borg|Bergen Fi.notes: One-act opera in Hungarian. Also known as A kékszakállú herceg vára. Libretto by Béla Balázs. Composed in 1911.

Brahms: Ungarske danser|Bergen Filharmon.notes: A set of 21 lively dance tunes based mostly on Hungarian themes. The original version was for piano four hands. Brahms orchestrated numbers 1, 3, and 10. Other composers have orchestrated the other dances.

Brahms: Symfoni nr. 1|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Brahms spent at least fourteen years completing Symphony No. 1, Op. 68, whose sketches date from 1854. The premiere was on November 4, 1876.

Matre: Different Stories|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Work by Norwegian composer Ørjan Matre.

Stravinsky: Vårofferet|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Ballet with music written by Igor Stravinsky. The innovative and complicated rhythmic structures and sounds, together with the extensive use of dissonances, make the piece one of the most important works of classical music in the 20th century. The uproar surrounding the premiere in 1913 made the work one of the most famous and controversial works in history.

Landkjenning|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkest.notes: Cantata for baritone, male chorus, orchestra and organ ad lib. The text by Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson is about Olav Tryggvason coming to Norway to Christianize the country. Also known as Land-Sighting.

Grieg: To elegiske melodier|Bergen Filha.notes: Also known as Two Elegiac Melodies. Originally for string orchestra. Op. 34 consists of transcriptions of two songs from Grieg's Op. 33 set to texts by Norwegian poet Aasmund Olavsson Vinje.

Grieg: Sigurd Jorsalfar|Bergen Filharmon.notes: Incidental music for a play by Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson celebrating King Sigurd I of Norway. An orchestral suite was later compiled as Op. 56.

Den Bergtekne|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkes.notes: For baritone, string orchestra and two horns. Also known as The Mountain Thrall.

Scener fra Olav Trygvason|Bergen Filharm.notes: Opera fragment (3 scenes). Libretto by Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson. Never completed due to a dispute between Grieg and Bjørnson. Grieg composed the music in 1873, and adapted it for concert performance in 1888-89.

To nordiske melodier for strykeorkester|.notes: Also known as Two Norwegian Airs. Composed in 1895. The 2nd item was arranged by Grieg from Nos.22 and 18 of 25 Norwegian Folk Songs and Dances, Op.17.

Symfoniske danser|Bergen Filharmoniske O.notes: The four Symphonic Dances Op. 64 by the Norwegian composer Edvard Grieg were written c. 1896 and published in 1897. They draw their inspiration from the earlier folk works collected by Ludvig Mathias Lindeman.

Grieg: Peer Gynt|Bergen Filharmoniske Or.notes: Incidental music to Henrik Ibsen's play. Grieg later created two suites from the music: Suite No. 1, Op. 46 and Suite No. 2, Op. 55.

Grieg: Foran Sydens Kloster|Bergen Filha.notes: Incidental music to Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson's Arnljot Gelline. For soprano, alto, female chorus and orchestra. Also known as 'At a southern convent's gate'.

Grieg: A-mollkonserten|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Composed in 1868. It was Grieg's only completed piano concerto. It is one of Grieg's most popular works. The first performance was on April 3, 1869.

Grieg: Pianokonsert i a-moll|Bergen Filh.work_title: Piano Concerto in A minor, Op. 16
Grieg: Pianokonsert i a-moll|Bergen Filh.notes: Grieg's only completed piano concerto and one of his most popular works. It was composed in 1868.

Berlioz: Grande messe des morts|Bergen F.notes: Also known as Requiem. Composed in 1837.

Verdi: Messa da Requiem|Bergen Filharmon.notes: Also known as the Manzoni Requiem, composed in memory of Alessandro Manzoni.

Highlights from BergenPhiLive|Bergen Fil.notes: Compilation of highlights performed by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester

Haydn: Symfoni nr. 83 ''Hønen''|Bergen F.notes: Also known as 'The Hen' (La Poule). Part of the Paris Symphonies.

Poulenc: Sinfonietta|Bergen Filharmonisk.notes: Composed in 1947 on a commission from the BBC, the Sinfonietta was first performed in London on 24 October 1948, conducted by Roger Désormière. The work is in four movements and is light and full of dance rhythms.

Sibelius: Luonnotar|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Tone poem for soprano and orchestra. Setting of Runo I of the Kalevala. Premiered in 1913.

Wigglesworth: Clocks from A Winter’s Tal.notes: Orchestral work based on themes from his opera 'The Winter's Tale'.

Wagner: Wesendonck-lieder|Bergen Filharm.notes: A set of five songs for female voice and piano. Also known as Fünf Gedichte für eine Frauenstimme (Five Poems for a Female Voice). He set five poems by Mathilde Wesendonck while he was working on his opera Tristan und Isolde. The songs, together with the Siegfried Idyll, are the two non-operatic works by Wagner most regularly performed.

Mozart: Fiolinkonsert nr. 5|Bergen Filha.work_title: Violin Concerto No. 5 in A major, K. 219
Mozart: Fiolinkonsert nr. 5|Bergen Filha.notes: Also known as the 'Turkish' Concerto. Written in 1775.

Adams: A Short Ride in a Fast Machine|Be.work_title: A Short Ride in a Fast Machine

Dvorak: Symfoni nr. 9 \"Fra den nye verd.work_title: Symphony No. 9 in E minor, "From the New World"
Dvorak: Symfoni nr. 9 \"Fra den nye verd.notes: Also known as the New World Symphony. Composed in 1893 while Dvořák was the director of the National Conservatory of Music of America. It premiered in New York City on December 16, 1893.

Hellstenius: As if the law is everything.work_title: As if the law is everything
Hellstenius: As if the law is everything.notes: Written in connection with the 200th anniversary of the Norwegian Constitution

Wagner: Faust-ouverture|Bergen Filharmon.notes: The Faust Overture is a concert overture by Richard Wagner, originally intended as the first movement of a Faust Symphony. Wagner abandoned the symphony, revising the overture in 1843-44 and again in 1855. It is one of his few compositions for the concert hall rather than the theatre.

Honegger: Symfoni nr. 3 ''liturgiske''|B.notes: Composed in 1945-1946, this symphony is also known as Symphonie Liturgique. It is in three movements, each named after a liturgical text: Dies irae, De profundis clamavi, and Dona nobis pacem.

Mozart: Requiem|Bergen Filharmoniske Ork.notes: Unfinished at the time of Mozart's death; completed by Franz Xaver Süssmayr. Also known as Requiem Mass in D minor.

Lyrisk suite|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkest.notes: Orchestration of four pieces from Lyric Pieces, Book V. Originally for solo piano. Orchestrated by Anton Seidl and Edvard Grieg. The original piano versions were composed between 1889-91 and published in 1891.

Brahms: Ein deutsches Requiem|Bergen Fil.notes: A large-scale work for chorus, orchestra, and soprano and baritone soloists, composed between 1865 and 1868. It is a sacred but non-liturgical work set in the German language.

Halvorsen: Fiolinkonsert|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Composed in 1908. The score was once thought to be lost, but was rediscovered in 2015. Dedicated to Kathleen Parlow.

Prokofiev: Pianokonsert nr. 5|Bergen Fil.notes: Composed in 1932. The concerto has five movements: Allegro con brio, Moderato ben accentuato, Toccata: Allegro con fuoco, Larghetto, and Vivo.

Holst: Planetene|Bergen Filharmoniske Or.notes: A seven-movement orchestral suite. Each movement is named after a planet and its astrological significance.

Elgar: Cellokonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.work_title: Cello Concerto in E minor, Op. 85
Elgar: Cellokonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Composed in 1919, Elgar's Cello Concerto in E minor, Op. 85, is a cornerstone of the cello repertoire. It is Elgar's last major completed work. The concerto has four movements. The first performance was a disaster because of inadequate rehearsal time. The work did not achieve wide popularity until the 1960s.

Grieg: Fra Peer Gynt|Bergen Filharmonisk.notes: Incidental music to Henrik Ibsen's play. Two suites were extracted later: Suite No. 1, Op. 46 and Suite No. 2, Op. 55.

Prokofiev: Symfoni nr. 3|Bergen Filharmo.work_title: Symphony No. 3 in C minor, Op. 44
Prokofiev: Symfoni nr. 3|Bergen Filharmo.notes: The music derives from Prokofiev's opera 'The Fiery Angel'. The symphony is in four movements and lasts approximately 30-35 minutes.

Sibelius: Folinkonsert|Bergen Filharmoni.work_title: Violin Concerto in D minor, Op. 47
Sibelius: Folinkonsert|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: The only concerto written by Sibelius.

Ravel: Daphnis et Chloë|Bergen Filharmon.notes: Ballet commissioned by Sergey Diaghilev. Symphonie chorégraphique for orchestra and chorus without words.

Tsjaikovskij: 1812-ouverture|Bergen Filh.notes: Commemorates Russia's successful defense against the French invasion in 1812. Also known as The Year 1812, Solemn Overture. Best known for its climactic volley of cannon fire, ringing chimes, and a brass fanfare finale.

Berlioz: Symphonie fantastique|Bergen Fi.notes: Berlioz's Symphonie fantastique is a five-movement symphonic work depicting an artist who falls in love and then, in a fit of hopelessness, poisons himself with opium. The artist's passion is represented by a recurring theme called the idée fixe. Berlioz was born on December 11, 1803, and died on March 8, 1869.

Brahms: Symfoni nr. 3|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Composed in 1883. Also known as Symphony No. 3 in F major, Opus 90. It is the shortest of Brahms' four symphonies.

Vaage: Tjat|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkeste.notes: Composed in 2005 and commissioned by Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra. 'Tjat' can be associated with bustle, throng and travel. The musicians of the orchestra are talking on top of each other, and not taking enough time to listen and reflect.

Elgar: Cellokonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.work_title: Cello Concerto in E minor, Op. 85
Elgar: Cellokonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Composed in 1919. Reflects a sense of melancholy and introspection. Premiered in London in October 1919.

FiB2016: Franz Liszt: Les préludes|Berge.notes: Symphonic poem composed between 1845 and 1854. Also known as 'The Beginnings'. It is the third of Liszt's thirteen symphonic poems. It began as an overture to Liszt's choral cycle Les quatre élémens (The Four Elements), then revised as a stand-alone concert overture, with a new title referring to a poem by Alphonse de Lamartine.

Hvoslef: Jubeljahr (1765)|Bergen Filharm.notes: Work by Johan Kvandal, performed by Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester

Hellstenius: Still Panic|Bergen Filharmo.notes: Recorded April 14, 2016 with the Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester

Paus: Paukekonsert|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: Written for the 250th anniversary of the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra. First performed on February 19, 2015. The premiere was broadcast by NRK. The work has generated debate about contemporary music.

Mozart: Store messe|Bergen Filharmoniske.notes: The Great Mass in C minor, K. 427, was composed in 1782 and 1783 in Vienna, but was never completed. Only the Kyrie and Gloria sections were completed. Other sections like Credo, Sanctus and Benedictus were incomplete, and Agnus Dei was missing entirely.

Mendelssohn: Hebridene|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Also known as Fingal's Cave. Inspired by Mendelssohn's visit to Fingal's Cave in Scotland.

Dvorak: Symfoni nr. 7|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Completed on 17 March 1885. Also referred to as Symphony No. 2. Key is D minor.

Schönberg: GurreLieder|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Gurre-Lieder is an oratorio for five vocal soloists, speaker, choir and large orchestra. The work is considered a highlight of late Romanticism. It was composed from 1900 to 1903, with orchestration completed in 1911. It premiered on February 23, 1913, in Vienna.

Matre: ''...yet from those flames no lig.notes: Scored for harp and orchestra, premiered in 2015 by the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra. Half of the orchestra is not visible during performance.

Vaage: Futuration|Bergen Filharmoniske O.notes: Futuration for orchestra and electronics, premiered by Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra in December 2015. Vaage is known for his work with hybrid acoustic/electronic soundscapes.

Knussen: Flourish with Fireworks|Bergen.notes: Written in 1988 as a celebratory opener for Michael Tilson Thomas' first season as principal conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra. It is a homage to Michael Tilson Thomas, the LSO, and Stravinsky. The music is built from the initials of the LSO (A, E-flat, G) and MTT (E, B, B).

Tsjaikovskij: Symfoni nr. 6 «Pathetique».notes: Also known as the Pathétique Symphony. The composer led the first performance in Saint Petersburg on October 28, 1893. The name Pathétique was suggested by Tchaikovsky's brother Modest.

Schubert: Symfoni nr. 8 «ufullendte»|Be.notes: Also known as the 'Unfinished Symphony'. It has only two completed movements.

Stravinsky: Fyrverkeri|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Also known as Fireworks, Op. 4. A short orchestral fantasy composed in 1908. It helped develop Stravinsky's reputation and caught the attention of Sergei Diaghilev.

Mahler: Symfoni nr. 1|Bergen Filharmonis.notes: Also known as Titan. Composed mainly between late 1887 and March 1888. The work was premièred at the Vigadó Concert Hall in Budapest, Hungary, in 1889, but was not well-received. Mahler made some major revisions for the second performance, given at Hamburg, Germany, in October 1893.

Hvoslef: Il Compleanno|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Written for the 220th anniversary of the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra. For symphony orchestra and 2 sextets.

Bergenssangen|Bergen Filharmoniske Orkes.notes: Also known as Bergensiana, Jeg tok min nystemte, and Nystemten. The melody is from an old French minuet. Johan Halvorsen wrote orchestral variations on the melody under the name Bergensiana.

Grieg: Olav Tryggvason|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Opera fragment (3 scenes) to text by Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson. The opera was never completed due to a series of unfortunate circumstances and misunderstandings between Grieg and Bjørnson. Grieg adapted the sketches for concert performance.

Haydn: Cellokonsert i C-dur|Bergen Filha.work_title: Cello Concerto No. 1 in C major
Haydn: Cellokonsert i C-dur|Bergen Filha.notes: Composed around 1761–1765. The work was presumed lost until 1961, when musicologist Oldřich Pulkert discovered a copy of the score at the Prague National Museum.

Rakhmaninov: Pianokonsert nr. 3|Bergen F.work_title: Piano Concerto No. 3 in D minor

Strauss: Don Quixote|Bergen Filharmonisk.notes: Fantastic Variations on a Theme of Knightly Character

Mahler: Symfoni nr. 4|Bergen Filharmoni.notes: Composed between 1899 and 1900. The symphony incorporates a song originally written in 1892. The final movement features a soprano singing 'Das himmlische Leben' ('The Heavenly Life'), presenting a child's vision of heaven.

Glagolitisk messe|Bergen Filharmoniske O.notes: Also called Missa Glagolitica or Slavonic Mass. Composition for soloists, double chorus, organ and orchestra. Completed in 1926. The Glagolitic alphabet was an early Slavic alphabet, the predecessor of the modern Cyrillic alphabet.

Mahler: Lieder eines fahrenden Gesellen|.notes: Song cycle for medium voice and orchestra. The texts were written by Mahler.

Svendsen: Romanse|Bergen Filharmoniske O.notes: Also known as Romance for Violin and Orchestra in D-flat major. Svendsen supposedly sketched the work in a couple of hours. It is Svendsen's most famous work.

Bull: Sæterjentens søndag|Bergen Filharm.notes: Sæterjentens søndag (The Herdgirl's Sunday) is Ole Bull's most famous melody. It comes from Et Sæterbesøg, composed in 1848. Et Sæterbesøg is a work composed of several independent pieces.

Griegs symfoni|Bergen Filharmoniske Orke.notes: Grieg wrote the symphony between 1863 and 1864. He later disowned it, marking the score 'Never to be performed'. The symphony has four movements.

Ole Bull: Polacca Guerriera|Bergen Filha.notes: Ole Bull (1810-1880) was a Norwegian virtuoso violinist and composer. Polacca Guerriera was composed in 1835 and revised in 1864. It exists in versions for violin and orchestra, and violin and piano.

Bach: Koralpreludium|Bergen Filharmonisk.notes: Koralpreludium is Norwegian for Chorale Prelude. Chorale preludes are short liturgical compositions for organ, using a chorale tune as its basis. Bach wrote many chorale preludes.

Tsjaikovskij: Symfoni nr. 5|Bergen Filha.work_title: Symphony No. 5 in E minor, Op. 64
Tsjaikovskij: Symfoni nr. 5|Bergen Filha.notes: Composed between May and August 1888. Dedicated to Theodor Avé-Lallemant. The symphony is cyclical, with a recurring main theme in all four movements.

Prokofiev: Symfoni nr. 1 ''Den klassiske.notes: Also known as 'Classical Symphony'. Composed in 1916-1917 as a reinterpretation of the classical style of Haydn and Mozart.

Flashmob på Flesland|Bergen Filharmonisk.notes: Performed as a flashmob at Flesland Airport on 2012-11-07 by the Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester.

Grubinger, Litton, Kates og Hofstätter|B.notes: Concert featuring Bergen Filharmoniske Orkester, Martin Grubinger, Andrew Litton, Peter Kates and Manuel Hofstätter. The specific works performed are not identified in the provided information.
